moreInfo:
Use `p? help [command]` for details on a command.

 Even more info can be found in the documentation at https://professorcalculus.io/docs

**Syntax**
> `[...]` denotes a required argument
> `(...)` denotes an optional argument
> `(-...)` denotes an optional flag. For example, if a command has the syntax `p? example (-x)` you can call it with `p? example` or `p? example -x` for different results
> `(-... [...])` denotes an optional flag with a required parameter

setup.description_short: The first command you should run after adding the bot to your server.

description.general:
This command will attempt to create the channel `#events` under a new category, events. This channel will automatically be registered as the events channel.

If the bot fails to create the `#events` channel, it will let you know and you will have to create one manually. Once a suitable channel has been created, you can set it as the events channel with the `configure channel` command.

This command can be run however many times, for instance if you accidentally remove the events channel, however, it will always create a new category, channel and role so you need to delete the old stuff manually.

You can always manually set the event channel with the `configure channel` command.

setup.notes: This command can only be executed by the server owner.

description.general: When this command is called without a subcommand, it will open up an interactive settings menu.

configure.notes: This command is only available to members with permission to configure roles.

args.[channel type]:
Available channel types are `events` and `friendly`.
> The `events` channel is the channel with the event list. **WARNING!** Setting a channel as the events channel will delete all messages therein.

> The `friendly` channel is the channel where reminders are sent for recurring events.

configure role.description_short: This command allows you to change the permissions for a certain `[@role]`.

description.general:
This command allows you to change the permissions for a certain [@role]. Roles that have the administrator permission already have all permissions for this bot.

Commands that require special permission to use are: 
> schedule
> remove
> update
> kick
> hook
> hook remove
> soundboard add
> soundboard remove
> configure channel
> configure role
> configure timezone
> notice new
> notice edit

If you are the owner of an event, you do not require any special permissions for commands related to that particular event.

description.general:
Starts the scheduling process for a new event.
Note that if any of the optional arguments above are provided, the corresponding step below will be skipped.
 The bot will ask you to give a title, date and time, description, optional roles and people limit for your new event. If at any time you want to cancel the scheduling process, type cancel. The process is as follows:
description.1. Name:
First you will be asked to provide a name for the event.

If the `(name)` optional argument is provided, this step will be skipped.
description.2. Date & Time:
Next you will be asked to give a date and a time for the event. It is important to note that you must specify the date **AND** time, e.g. `June 15th 2020 at 14:00`. 

Almost all date formats are supported, however, the order `day/month/year` is the default when the name of the month is not specified.

 If the date specified includes a weekday (e.g. `Thursdays at 12:00`), the event will be set as recurring at the same time every week.
If an event is recurring then instead of removing the event once it starts, the attendant list will simply be cleared.
At 10:00 A.M. on a day with a recurring event the bot will post a little message in the designated friendly channel (see configure channel for details).
 You can also specify that an event is yet to be dated by entering `TBD` as the date.

If the `(date & time)` optional argument is provided, this step will be skipped.
description.3. Description:
Third, you will be asked to provide a description for your event.

If the `(description)` optional argument is provided, this step will be skipped.
description.4. Roles:
After asking you for a description, the bot will ask you to react to a message with emojis to represent any event specific roles. Once you have added all your reactions, type `done` in the text channel. You will then have to give a name and a limit of people for each role.

If you are not in need of any event specific roles, type done without reacting to the message with any emojis.
These roles are purely visual and no actual server roles are added.

If the `(-noroles)` optional flag is provided, this step will be skipped.
description.5. Limit:
Lastly, you will be asked to specify how many people in total can join your event. If a limit of `0` is specified, an unlimited number of people will be able to join.

If the `(limit)` optional argument is provided, this step will be skipped.
description.Owner: When scheduling an event, you will be registered as the event owner and thus do not require any other event related permissions when executing commands related to this event.

examples: p? schedule "Example event" tomorrow "Come join us for some fun!" 2 -noroles
schedule.notes:
1. This command is only available to members with permission (see `p? help configure role` for details).

2. You cannot change the order of the optional arguments (except for that `-noroles` can be placed anywhere in the command). Your first argument will always be interpreted as `(name)`, the second as `(date & time)` and so on.

args.[event id]: The id of the event to be removed.

description.general: Removes the event number `[event id]`.

remove.notes: This command is only available to members with permission and the owner of the event (see `p? help configure role` for details).

args.[event id]: The id of the event to attend.

description.general:
Signs you up for event number `[event id]` and adds your name to the list of people showing up.

You can also use this command to change your role in an event. To do so, simply attend the event again.

attend.description_short: Signs you up for event number `[event id]` or lets you pick a different role for that event.

args.[event id]: The id of the event to leave.

description.general: Use this command to leave event number `[event id]` and remove your name from the list of people showing up.

args.[event id]: The id of the event to update
args.[what to update]:
The field to update.

Available fields are
> `date`:	The date and time of the event. The same formats as in schedule.
> `name`:	The name of the event.
> `description`:	The description of the event
> `owner`:	The owner of the event. When updating this field, use the `@Mention` for the new owner as `[new value]`
> `limit`:	The limit of people that can join this event.
> `role`: Edit a role
args.[new value]: The thing to change `[what to update] to.

description.general: This command sets the field `[what to update]` to `[new value]` for event number `[event id]`.
description.Editing roles:
When editing a role, the command syntax becomes as follows: 
```
p? update [event id] role [the role's emoji] [attribute] [new value]
```
Available values for `[attribute]` are:
> `name`:	The name of the role
> `limit`:	The limit of people who can join a role
> `emoji`:	The role's emoji. When updating this attribute, `[new info]` can be left blank.

examples: p? update 2 description Free oj for everyone who shows up.
update.description_short: This command sets the field `[what to update]` to `[new value]` for event number `[event id]`.
update.notes: This command is only available to members with permission and the owner of the event (see `p? help configure role` for details).

description.general:
This command generates a random julia set unless a `(complex number)` is specified, then it will generate the set with the given constant. You can choose the colour scheme by specifiyng `(colour scheme)`.

If neither parameter is specified, you will receive a random Julia set.

> Salt count
> All reminders you have set and have not yet deleted
> All spoiler messages you have sent with the spoiler command and have not yet been deleted
> You will be removed from all scheduled events
When this command is invoked without a subcommand it will list all the available sounds and you will be able to pick one to play.

args.[name]: The name of the new sound to be added.

description.general: To add a new sound, upload a mp3 or wav file to any channel the bot has access to and put this command in the comment when uploading. The new sound will be called `[name]`.

soundboard add.description_short: Add a new sound and call it `[name]`.
soundboard add.notes:
1. Sound names cannot include spaces.

2. If you delete the message with the file upload, then that sound will no longer work.

3. This command is only available to members with permission (see `p? help configure role` for details).

4. The maximum amount of sounds for a server is 19.

args.[name]: The name of the sound to remove.

description.general: This command will remove the sound called `[name]`.

soundboard remove.notes: This command is only available to members with permission (see `p? help configure role` for details).

args.[name]: The name of the sound to play.

description.general: This command will play the sound called `[name]`. To see all available sounds, use the Soundboard command.

args.[old name]: The name of the sound to rename.
args.[new name]: The new name for the sound.

description.general: This command will rename the sound `[old name]` to `[new name]`.

soundboard rename.description_short: Rename the sound `[old name]` to `[new name]`
soundboard rename.notes: This command is only available to members with permission (see `p? help configure role` for details).

args.[time]: The time you want to set the reminder for.
args.[reminder]: What you want to be reminded of

description.general: This command will set a reminder for `[reminder]` which will go off at `[time]`.

examples: p? remindme in 2 days to water my cactus
p? remindme tomorrow at 14:30 UTC-3 to put cookies in the oven
remindme.notes: All times are in UTC if not otherwise specified.

args.(page): The page you want to check. This parameter is optional.

description.general: This command will give you a list of reminders you have set for yourself as well as their ids.

args.[reminder id]: The id of the reminder you want to delete.

description.general: This command will remove the reminder with the given `[reminder id]`. You can check all your reminders and their ids with the `remindme list` command.
